title: Understanding the Photoelectric Effect
text: The photoelectric effect occurs when light shines on a metal surface and electrons are emitted. The energy of the incoming photons must be greater than the work function of the metal for electrons to be emitted.

title: Photon Energy Formula
text: The energy of a photon can be calculated using the formula: $$E=hf$$, where E is the energy, $$h$$ is Planck's constant (6.626×10**-34 J·s), and f is the frequency of the photon.

title: Relating Photon Energy to Kinetic Energy
text: The energy of the incoming photon is used to overcome the work function of the metal and provide kinetic energy to the emitted electron. This relationship is given by: $$E_{photon}=Φ+KE_{max}$$, where Φ is the work function and $$KE_{max}$$ is the maximum kinetic energy of the emitted electron.

title: Calculate Photon Energy
text: Using the formula $$E=hf$$, calculate the energy of the photon with a frequency of 1.04×10**15 $$s^{-1}$$.

title: Calculate the Work Function
text: Using the relationship $$E_{photon}=Φ+KE_{max}$$, rearrange the formula to solve for the work function Φ. Then, substitute the values for $$E_{photon}$$ and $$KE_{max}$$ to find Φ.
